docs.lead_paragraph: THIS month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the nation's unemployment rate had fallen slightly in May, to 4.4 percent. The decline was the first in nine months, and with many stocks rising again, it suggested that the economic slowdown of 2001 might be near its end. But that measure was almost the only labor-market gauge to improve in May. Fewer people held jobs than in April. More people applied for unemployment insurance. A greater percentage of those without jobs had been fired or laid off rather than had quit. And a larger number of people who wanted full-time work could find only part-time work.
docs.abstract: Federal government's statistics on unemployment may give distorted picture of true labor market because government does not count as unemployed people who would like to work but who have given up trying to find job; were these people counted, unemployment rate would double; preference for rosier data sums up conflicting attitude that United States, and virtually all free-market socities, hold toward joblessness; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THIS month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the nation's unemployment rate had fallen slightly in May, to 4.4 percent. The  decline was the first in nine months, and with many stocks rising again, it suggested that the  economic slowdown...

docs.lead_paragraph: STANDING in a business suit, his back to a wide chalkboard and his face toward an amphitheater that was packed save a few seats in the front row, Richard B. Turan looked and at times sounded like a college professor teaching his first class. ''You cannot run a $400 million company without data,'' lectured Mr. Turan, the president of the Nassau Health Care Corporation, the public benefit corporation that runs the Nassau University Medical Center, seven clinics and the A. Holly Patterson nursing home. ''You can't do it based on what you feel.''
docs.abstract: Article on shakeup that has taken place at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, Long Island, under new leadership of Richard B Turan; Turan has eliminated 24 doctors' positions, 20 staff positions and consolidated work of others at estimated savings of $4 million a year, startling employees and drawing fire from Civil Service Employees Assn; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HUGH HAWTHORNE is not a man easily impressed. But he sounded positively rhapsodic when describing his treatment in February at the Sentara Medical Group in Norfolk, Va. ''All through the day it was, 'Can I get you some water? Do you need anything? Is the water too cold?' '' said Mr. Hawthorne, a 70-year-old construction industry executive who lives in Richmond. ''And they served a great breakfast, with ham and eggs, bagels and all kinds of jams and jellies.''

headline.main: The Standard Checkup? Well, Not Exactly

docs.abstract: Dozens of health care institutions are offering executive physicals for patients who can afford to pay for them; services combine personal attention with latest medical technology and testing that goes far beyond typical check-up; rates for executive physicals at best-known centers are $1,500 to $3,000; since exams are considered preventive care, health-insurance plans almost never cover them; growing number of health care institutions are jumping into this high-end market, after years of being squeezed by cutbacks in reimbursement rates from private and government insurance programs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a cramped room at the Mount Sinai Hospital's Cardiac Care Center, time is marked by the loud, mechanical beating of Louis Fantauzzi's artificial heart. It is the sound of a tethered life, a life in suspension. Now in his fifth month of waiting for a real heart, Mr. Fantauzzi embraces distraction. He loses himself in books. He soars with the voice of Celine Dion on his headset. Twice a day he attaches a battery-operated power pack to his stand-in heart and takes 15-minute walks through the antiseptic corridors. Most of all, he longs for his doctor to stride into the room and say: we have a match.

headline.main: Three Who've Learned The Hardest Way

docs.abstract: Diseases of the heart return to spotlight, thanks in part to much-publicized heart conditions of television personality Dave Letterman and Vice Pres Dick Cheney; heart disease is nation's leading cause of death, but cardiologists stress that remarkable advances in preventing and treating heart disease have been made in just last 15 years or so; article traces cases of three men battling various forms of heart disease: one who is waiting for transplant, one who has enlarged heart, and one with family history of heart attack who has already had heart attack himself, at age 36; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT BUSH'S idea was simple enough: First thing we do, let's kill all the death taxes. . . . The execution, alas, was not so simple.

headline.main: Coping With a Tax That Has Nine Lives

docs.abstract: David Cay Johnston article on complexities introduced into estate planning by Pres Bush's new tax law, which will gradually reduce estate taxes and repeal them in year 2010 only to resurrect them in 2001 and which is laced with many subtle provisions that can cause the uninformed to pay taxes unnecessarily, leave heirs much more or much less than was intended and, perhaps, prompt litigation among family members; outlines strategies for avoiding pitfalls; drawings; graph (M)
docs.snippet: PRESIDENT BUSH'S idea was simple enough: First thing we do, let's kill all the death taxes. . . .    The execution, alas, was not so simple.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a New York Knick, Fred Crawford suited up with Bill Bradley and Willis Reed. Later he was a member of the Los Angeles Lakers when Elgin Baylor and Jerry West were the stars of that team. He ended his career with the Milwaukee Bucks, whose center was Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. That was three decades ago. Late last month, as he entered a medical office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, Mr. Crawford moved in what must have seemed like slow motion to him. Decades of constant pounding had taken their toll on his left hip. Pain and weakness prevented him from walking more than three blocks at a time. ''Basketball is a tough business, but you're not thinking about that at the time,'' Mr. Crawford said. His diagnosis: moderately severe osteoarthritis.

headline.main: New Weapons to Assault an Epidemic

docs.abstract: About 21 million Americans are afflicted with osteoarthritis; figure is expected to soar to more than 30 million by 2020, as baby boomers grow older; women stand greater chance than men of developing disease, but some arthritis experts are seeing more men developing severe cases, and earlier, in their 50's rather than 60's or 70's, which may be attributed to more participation in strenuous sports; description of variety of promising treatments and technological advances; photo (M)
docs.snippet: AS a New York Knick, Fred Crawford suited up with Bill Bradley and Willis Reed. Later he was a member of the Los Angeles Lakers when Elgin Baylor and Jerry West were the stars of that team. He ended his career with the Milwaukee Bucks, whose center...

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER Sharon Maynard's husband of 20 years decided he did not want to be married anymore, she felt her life slipping out of control -- and felt herself slipping into depression. As a single mother of a teenage son, she did not know what to think and what to do and, least of all, where to turn for help. A year after her ordeal, Ms. Maynard, a 42-year-old purchasing agent, says she found solace from a source that may sound unlikely but is increasingly available to American workers: her employer.

headline.main: A Place Where They Don't Dread Coming to Work

docs.abstract: About 90 percent of companies with at least 50 employees have program to promote healthy living that is aimed at decreasing health care costs and increasing employee productivity; programs vary from exercise classes to discounts on health insurance premiums; nearly all can have striking effect on production and women have record of participating more than men; photo; graph (M)
docs.snippet: AFTER Sharon Maynard's husband of 20 years decided he did not want to be married anymore, she felt her life slipping out of control -- and felt herself slipping into depression. As a single mother of a teenage son, she did not know what to think and...

docs.lead_paragraph: FIVE years have passed since Lee Chew was paralyzed and close to death with AIDS. But not until he stood up last month to receive both his master's degree in social work from New York University and a special award for his clinical skills did he finally feel his new life was starting. His 83-year-old mother from Virginia sat in the audience. Mr. Chew, 52, saw her after the ceremony. ''She just said she was very proud of me, and she had tears in her eyes and she was beaming,'' Mr. Chew said. ''It was important to me to see that reflected in her face. It was a blow telling my family I was H.I.V.-positive and having my mother looking forward to the possibility of burying me.''

headline.main: Taking Risks, Moving On: A Follow-Up Visit With Eight Outpatients

docs.abstract: Follow-up visit with eight outpatients who described last year how they live with their diseases: Lee Chew, who has AIDS, Janis Spurlock-McLendon, who has sickle cell anemia, Robert O Boorstin, who is manic-depressive, Mary Taylor Previte, who lost hand in buzz-saw accident, Richard Cohen, who has multiple sclerosis, Elizabeth Yoffe, who suffered stroke, Tom DeBaggio, who has Alzheimer's disease, and Dale O'Reilley, who chose to end her life after 10 years of suffering with Lou Gehrig's disease; photos (M)
docs.snippet: FIVE years have passed since Lee Chew was paralyzed and close to death with AIDS. But not until he stood up last month to receive both his master's degree in social work from New York University and a special award for his clinical skills did he...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE health maintenance organization plans are starting to lose favor around the United States, they are booming in New Haven and Meriden, so much so that last year that region had a higher percentage of H.M.O. patients than any other metropolitan area in the country, according to a study released last week. Between July 1999 and July 2000, H.M.O. plans across the United States lost 700,000 people. But in the New Haven-Meriden area, H.M.O. plans gained 55,533 people during that period, continuing a four-year rise.

headline.main: Study on H.M.O.'s Targets the State

docs.abstract: InterStudy Publications releases results of analysis showing that while health maintenance organizations are losing favor around US, they are booming in New Haven and Meriden, Conn; more than 73 percent of towns' populations are patients in one of ten HMO plans (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush, in a surprise to many on Capitol Hill, said today that he would support the passage of a law preventing insurance companies and employers from using newly developed tests of people's genetic makeup to deny them medical coverage or turn them down for jobs. Mr. Bush declared his support for such restrictions on the use of information gleaned from a person's DNA in his weekly radio address, broadcast as he spent a long weekend at his ranch near here in Crawford.

headline.main: Bush Supports Federal Law Putting Limits On DNA Tests

docs.abstract: Pres Bush says he will support passage of law preventing insurance companies and employers from using newly developed tests of people's genetic makeup to deny them medical coverage or turn them down for jobs; declares his support for restrictions on use of information gleaned from person's DNA in his weekly radio address (M)
